comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: 2's company and 30 is a crowd! The expression Jam Packed comes to mind. Yes Carol, you're dead right he has a camera in his hand.  I would have expected a Breviary but that is indeed one of those dreaded camera thingys!  The priest on the other wing has a sister on either side and the resemblance is remarkable, there is a great sense of love and pride between them as they snuggle in together, really lovely to see.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content:
The groom looks slightly worried, the bride looks self-assured.
Lots of happy people on the bride's side of the picture.
I like the woman in profile.

comment.author: 38088948@N05
comment._content: perfect! :)

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content: Yes the priest is holding a camera, like the ones here in my collection;

comment.author: 54082333@N00
comment._content: It could be a camera, hard to tell, could also be a case for holding religious pieces such as holy water, oils etc? Though the "buckle" at the right does look like it could wind on something like film. NOW, **huge** "leap of faith" here on the priest... if it is a camera could it be Fr Francis Browne? If I was forced to say yes or no based on what I have right now I'd say no but maybe there are other photos or evidence that may prove it one way or the other. The only photos I can find of him he is much older or younger but it's not impossible that it is him. In 1922 he would have been 42. Most of the people here will have seen Fr Brownes photos from the Titanic. Older: www.independent.ie/national-news/unseen-snapshots-of-a-na... www.clarecourier.ie/article.asp?id=3051 fatherdoyle.com/2011/08/02/thoughts-about-fr-willie-doyle... Younger: www.titanicphotographs.com/ Update: Just saw juffrouwjo's comment. Looks like it is a camera then so that would strengthen a case for it possibly being Fr Browne.

comment.author: 99684904@N00
comment._content: I am 100% sure it indeed is a camera.

comment.author: 24113450@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/decsramble] I dont think its Father Browne . I've seen older images and he is much less follicly-challenged than the priest in this photo. 
Nice thought  though.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
He is definitely holding a folding camera, a 120 or 116.
Kodak introduced the slimmer 620 and 616 much later, in the 1930s.

comment.author: 54082333@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/24113450@N00] Yeah, it's a stretch, would have been interesting but if other photos discount it's not him.

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/]
Camera ?  Nah, this is an Irish Wedding; that's a flask!

Cheers!

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/hab3045] 
I have had a look at your vintage camera photos. Excellent!
I used a pre-War Kodak Junior 620 folding camera in 1958.
The only snag was getting a pinhole in the black paper bellows which made flare marks on the film.
Folding cameras had better lenses and shutters than Box Brownies.
In 1961 I used a folding Kodak Sterling 620 camera with Agfa colour film.

comment.author: 54082333@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hab3045] Lovely old cameras and photos, you're very lucky to have access to history events through your job :-)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Isn't it hilarious? All of these photos, and with the exception of a few that include a news cameraman, this is the first actual camera we've seen, I think?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content:
Photography went downhill when the professional using a heavy wooden camera with big glass slides was joined by the amateur. That is when out-of-focus blurry photos started to appear. 
It's good to see so many big sharp photos on this NLI photostream.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Ah, that's the good old glass plates for you!
